timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 14, 2022

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great, affordable monitoring/mixing headphones (ATH-M70x)
author: Dan-O
content: I'm sure other people have noted this in their reviews, but in the hopes of preventing more, "Beats by Dre are better than these!" types of reviews/comments, it needs to be made clear that these headphones are not made for casual listening. These are reference headphones, designed to have a flat, accurate sound. Beats by Dre and other consumer-level headphones are good at what they are intended for, but they are not good at what these headphones are intended for.If you are making music and need to mix and master your work, these headphones are great for that. Their dynamic range is ridiculous - you can hear extremely low lows and high highs that you're unlikely to hear on consumer headphones because consumer headphones intentionally flatten the range and boost certain frequencies to make music sound "better" to the masses. These and other reference headphones try to capture every nuance and defect so that you can catch them in your mixing and mastering process.All told, I'm very impressed with these headphones. The first time I put them on I almost sighed at how comfortable they are compared to the much cheaper headphones I'd been using. The sound is clear and the range is immediately noticeable once you start listening to kick drums and basslines and hear artifacts that you might not pick up with a narrower dynamic range.For me, these are just what I needed - well-made, comfortable, great sound, reasonable price (I got them on sale for $250).I would recommend these for others like me who are starting to take their music production from casual hobbyist to serious student. For those just starting to write/arrange/produce music, I would recommend focusing your budget on other areas, like a good DAW or some of the better VST synths, or hardware midi controllers, etc. Those types of things will be a much better investment early on and will expand your creative possibilities far more than good headphones will.With that said, if you have the money to burn or have a need for some high-quality, reasonably-priced reference headphones, these are a good place to start.These came with a form-fitted carrying case, a coiled cable, a straight cable, and an adapter for the cords. The cords are detachable and lock into place with a twist.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 29, 2018

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Cheaper, Better options are available
author: pH
content: Starting a new job at a company with an open workspace floor plan. That's going to be tough, though I. Maybe some closed back headphones will provide me with a small sense of isolation....So, I listened to a bunch, listed below in my order of preference, with my favorites at the top.These are all closed back, with prices ranging from $120 up to $300. Music source was a laptop connected to a DAC/Headphone Amp via USB. (I also tested various DAC/Amps but the headphones make the larger difference.)I've kept notes on my impressions brief and included comparisons amongst the headphones in this list. If you want flowery vocabulary I'm sure in depth reviews are available out there on the web.---beyerdynamic DT 700 PRO X Closed-Back Studio HeadphonesVery good. Get you involved with the music. Brighter than A990Z but not painfully so. I don't think these would be fatiguing. Bass solid but not overemphasized.Very comfortable. Feel secure.Audio-Technica ATH-A990Z Art Monitor Closed-Back Dynamic HeadphonesGood. Balanced. Not overly bright. Good space. Etherial. One could definitely listen to these all day without fatigue.Fit: Feel loose. Odd headband. Cans are LARGE.Audio-Technica ATH-M50X Professional Studio Monitor HeadphonesGood. Bright. Maybe too bright. Yet not as clear as the 700 PRO X.Comfort is ok. There's a bit more pressure around the ears than some, and the cans are on the smaller side so positioning them is key.beyerdynamic DT 770 Pro 32 ohm Limited Edition Professional Studio HeadphonesGood. Less efficient than the 700 PRO X, which doesn't make a ton of sense since these claim to have lower impedance. Significanty brighter than the 700 PRO X. They do lack bass - noticible even with male vocals.Very comfortable.Audio-Technica ATH-M70X Closed-Back Dynamic Professional Studio Monitor HeadphonesBright, but lack bass. It's just not there. Scarcely more bass than the MSR7b8K's. I'd say these are "vocal forward" - lots of detail in the vocal range.I prefer the M50X. Slightly more base. Slightly warmer.Comfort is good.Audio-Technica ATH-MSR7bBK Over-Ear High-Resolution HeadphonesOK. Bright. Lack body (weak bass).Light. Short cord.Did not come with a 1/4" plug or an adapter. Clearly intended for a pocket source.Audio-Technica ATH-A550Z Art Monitor Closed-Back Dynamic HeadphonesBad. Lack midrange. Too much trebble.If you like this style I strongly recommend that you save a bit and get the ATH-A990Z.Comfortable, but feel a bit loose. Huge cans.SENNHEISER HD 569 Closed Back HeadphoneBad. Disappointing. Total lack of detail. Cymbals present in other headphones are scarcely noticed.Large-ish, tall cans.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 11, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing Flat-Response Headphones!
author: P. E. Allen
content: As a professional musician, composer, orchestrator, finding a great pair flat-response headphones have been critically important and quite a journey! Examining and comparing many models and their criteria, of both very expensive models and not-so much, has led me to the Audio-Technica ATH-M70X. Am totally blown away! The very smooth, even response, very low to very high, is simply amazing! Listening to John Williams conducting his sensitive theme from "Schindler's List," and hearing/feeling not only the emotions of violin solo, but the violin bow buzz-on-the-string nuance is rather incredible! As others have stated, these are NOT attenuated to add highs or lows, but a true picture of the uncolored, flat-response, pure sound. These are perfect for audio recording engineers and for mixing a clear unadulterated audio picture. Note: DO NOT expect to compare these to other headphones which are used for average, every day leisurely listening, there are tons of those around. ~~ Next, I just listened to a large symphony orchestra with a large pipe organ, VERY smooth and clear response over the entire frequency range of an astonishing 5 to 40,000 hertz! ~~ To try different musical styles, I tried a bit of LL Cool J - still a clear and an awesome pure sound! ~~ Then, a bit of Jacob Collier - such eclectic and a wide variety of sounds - everything clear and transparent! ~~ Then, some a Cappella vocals with Straight No Chaser - heard intricate nuances never heard before. ~~ Then, pure symphony orchestra of Cody Fry's "Eleanor Rigby" - am simply blown away at the transparency! ~~ Then, a bit of jazz with Harry Connick Jr - each and every note of his artistry shines through. (Lastly, comfort-wise they sit nicely and comfortably on both the ears and the head for long-term use.) HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars No Buyer's Remorse From Me.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2015

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Give a lot of clarity. Not for listeners who favor a warm sound.
author: Derek Lynch
content: Notes: Headphone reviews are highly subjective. I greatly favor having a warm sound. CNET's Review is a good place to start for an idea of what these headphones offer.I am fan of many types of music and also a warm sound. I purchased these headphones because I wanted to find a more enveloping and "high end" listening experience beyond my Koss Porta Pro headphones (which are a much loved base point for pretty much all of my music listening). Beyond CNET's review of these headphones, I wanted to share my experience from the desire to find a higher end experience.These headphones have tons of clarity. If you are looking to hear detail in your recordings these will give you that. There is so much detail that they will reveal issues in streaming quality and recording flaws. In this regard these meet the expectation of "high res" as described. I find this is achieved at the sacrifice of some low end and especially mid range (which is scooped) and overall warmth.Listening to Don't Trust Myself from John Mayer's Continuum album, these headphones seemed to have an relatively even balance with good clarity in the highs along with definition and punch in the bass. With it being such a warm recording I found the previously stated tonal characteristics to not stand out too much. It wasn't until i branched into other music that it became more and more noticeable.Noteworthy examples would be In acoustic guitar recordings (e.g. Don Ross), choral music (e.g. Eric Whitacre) and classical (e.g. Tannhauser: Overature by Wagner). In these I found that they were too bright overall for my taste. Listening to Dirty Loops i found the bass to be clear but the synth, keys and other sounds were shrill to the point of not being able to listen to more than one track.I am returning these to find another option because although they give clarity, are comfortable to wear, look cool and have a nice over the ear experience (decent sound isolation with a breathable design), they are too bright for my listening preferences.If you want clarity and are fine with some brightness, these are for you. If you like warmth or want really strong bass, you would do well to look elsewhere.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Absolute Best Headphones I've Owned......So Far!
author: Goonior
content: I've been trying to find something in a headphone that sounds this amazing for several years. My quest started about 7 yrs ago with a set of Sony V-6's Sony MDRV6 Studio Monitor Headphones with CCAW Voice Coil , crisp and clean sound, but the highs were too harsh to listen to at moderate volume for too long, I gave them to my daughters to use when I bought the Koss Pro DJ 100's. They used the V-6's until the earpads fell apart. They have since moved on to earbuds, oh well.... The DJ100's Koss ProDJ100 Headphones were MUCH better! Warm, clean sound and easily driven, they were my go to headphones for a few years until I recently bought the Koss Pro 4s. The Pro 4s Koss Pro4S Full Size Studio Headphones, Black with Silver Trim were an improvement over the 100's and was very happy with them, but as always I'm looking for better headphones than what I had previously. I had gone about as far as I could with Koss Headphones, the next step up was their ESP "phones" Koss ESP-950 Electrostatic Stereophone but at about a grand each and the lack of portability, for those reasons they weren't even a consideration. What can I say about them that hasn't already been said? These are the absolute best headphones I've owned, so far... I bought the Audio-Technica MSR7BK to pair with my new Fiio X3 2nd Gen FiiO X3-II High Resolution Music Player (Newest Model) (Black) . First listen straight out of the box they sounded a little on the bright side, but not harsh. After some time they did seem to settle down (could just be my ears adjusting to them, too. I'm still on the fence about burn-in) and sound just the way I had hoped. Side by side with 4s, they both seem to be just as accurate at reproducing sound, but the Audio-Technica's beat them out in the higher frequency range revealing even MORE detail than was possible with the Koss, amplifier noise that was non existent from my Dell d630 laptop (plays 192/24 FLAC perfectly fine) with the Koss revealed itself with the Audio-Technica's. More to come.......
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 2, 2017

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Beautiful headphone with detailed mids/highs, though bright; uncomfortable for long listening sessions
author: micaelaSR
content: It's a great headphone, with detailed mids and highs. I own a pair of Fidelio X2s, but I needed a pair of closed cans to block out fan noise in the dorm.Compared to those X2s, the high end has much more presence. Guitars and synths sound crisp and impactful. These headphones don't have the sub-bass "slam" the X2s do, however, and that's something I miss.My only complaints would be the sibilance in the 10kHz region. I've tried to reduce it with a foobar2000 EQ plugin, but I haven't been able to tame it. I ran these out of a Schiit Stack 2 (Modi 2, Magni 2, vanilla non-uber versions), a solid-state setup known for its analytical sound. I believe pairing a bright source with a bright headphone is the problem; the highs sound fantastic, but often harsh. I've heard that these headphones sound great with a good tube amp. Also, I used these headphones in an environment with lots of fan noise in the background, and the fans drowned out most of the MSR7's low end. These aren't meant to be noise-cancelling, but keep this in mind if you're going to be using this in a room with tons of white noise.What ultimately forced me to return these headphones was the discomfort I experienced. I wear glasses with thick rims, and they hurt to wear with these headphones. My ear touched the drivers in the cup too, meaning I had to take the MSR7s off every 20 minutes or so.Overall, I'm glad I bought this pair of headphones. Coming from X2s, I've heard a clarity in the mids/highs that I've never heard before. Without these, I wouldn't understand the value of high-quality upper frequencies.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 31, 2016

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Astounding Sound Quality
author: F. Nicole
content: These are very nice. The midrange, in particular female vocals, shines with these headphones. Tight, accurate bass. Think quality over quantity in this case. Treble and detail in general are spectacular. They are extremely revealing. If a file is of poor quality or recorded in low quality, these headphones will expose them.They are not the best at isolating outside noises. You would have to really pump up the volume to block street noises, for example. Personally, I like that I can hear loud sounds around me. I would not enjoy sounds being completely shut off from me while commuting. In a normal office environment, though, I can barely hear outside sounds.A couple of things prevent this product from being perfect for me. First is the comfort. The earpads are soft, but shallow. Most ears will touch the material covering the drivers. They also fit tightly on one's head. It does not bother me, as I have what is considered to be a small head, but those with larger heads may have to make some effort at stretching the headband to their comfort.The cables included seem to be of poor quality. They are thin, have major wire memory, and very poor strain relief. I've already gone through one of the 3 provided (I bought these in October), due to a short developing when using these headphones with a cellphone in a case. For a portable headphone, a fragile cable is almost unacceptable, in my opinion. Audio Technica, please give us stronger cables!Overall, I believe these headphones are a great value in spite of the few negatives I experienced. The sound quality alone is worth 90% of the price for these.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 9, 2015

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Phenomenal
author: Donna More
content: Short Review: It's simply the absolute best headphone in the around $400 if you want noise-isolating flat frequency response headphones. I have tested these along side at about 15 headphones (see below for list) in this price range and these were simply the best by far in terms of sound quality. Period. Not only in total, but also each section (sound stage, bass, treble, mids). It's build quality isn't the best when it comes to its feel but it'll last at least a decade.Long Review:Sound Stage: not a single closed-back headphone even comes close, not even the M70x which is very similar to this headphone.Bass: Not boosted like the headphones designed for the current fad but still some head-shaking action on dubstep or hiphop tracks. I never heard a track with this that I thought the bass was drowning or lackingTreble: Crazy crisp. Although the bass and mids don't even come close to lacking, the treble is where it can't get any better. I've tried a +$2500 (two zeros) open back headphone and amp setup (an HD800 through a DNA Stratus) and the treble on this headphone was the same. Compared to it. Besides that setup, nothing is even comparable to this headphone's treble.Mids: Crazy accurateBuild Quality: Doesn't feel the best but will definitely last at least a decade and a half. It creaks when you stretch it out so doesn't give it the best feel. Also, the cable's connector isn't rubber so I feel like it'll break if it bangs around too much.Cons: The creaking, the hard plastic casing jack, synthetic ear-pads (HM5 ear pads fix the over-heating and size issues its stock earpads have), cable has a lot of memory, no volume control on the cable, my hair sometimes gets pulled, and finally, a bit tight when you rest them around your head.Headphones I tested along side this:Sennheiser Momentum on-earSennheiser Momentum 2 on-earSennheiser Momentum around-earSennheiser Momentum 2 around-earV-MODA Crossfade M-100V-MODA Crossfade M-80Sennheiser HD 380 ProBeats ProBeats Studio (the new one)Beats Studio (the old one)Sony MDR-1aB&W P7B&W P5Parrot ZikBeyerdynamic DT-990BeoPlay H8BeoPlay H6Audio-Technica ATH-M50Audio-Technica ATH-M70x
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 31, 2015

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent sound quality, and the NC's don't have the build/comfort issues of the non-NC's
author: Jordan
content: **Note that this review is for the NC version of the MSR7's**I've been on the fence about writing a review for these since I haven't owned other pairs of high quality headphones. Having said that, though, I do listen to a wide variety of music (electronic, rap, indie, pop, classical, etc.), and I've listened to the music I like enough to know what it 'should' sound like. So take this review for what it's worth given that context.If you're reading this review, you've probably already read the extremely detailed review of the non-NC MSR7's posted by DM. It's worth noting that in their MSR7NC release, Audio-Technica seems to have addressed all of the 'cons' listed in the build/appearance/comfort sections of his/her review of the MSR7's. The NC's are comfortable, non-creaky, and there are no other noticeable issues with the build/cable.I've also seen a lot of reviews cautioning bass-heads away from these headphones. I can hear where those people are coming from -- the MSR7's won't blast bass by default. But they do have a balanced overall frequency response -- the bass level is where it should be. And the quality of the bass is excellent; texture and depth are well preserved. Personally, my conclusion after reading those reviews and listening to these headphones is that people complaining about a lack of bass are used to bass-heavy headphones like Beats. Having said that, if you have access to an equalizer, you can adjust the bass to suit your preferences -- bumping it up a bit won't affect the quality of the bass.Overall, I've found the sound quality across a variety of genres to be excellent. The noise cancellation won't block out absolutely everything, but it also won't affect the sound quality or make your ears feel like they're in a vaccuum chamber. It does enough in the settings I've tested it in to keep distractions from detracting from your experience of the music without totally detaching you from the world around you.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 14, 2017

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Audio-technica hit a home run
author: Pfpb
content: These closed Audio - Technica headsets are outstanding. I have been looking for a good solid set of cans with a great sound without breaking the bank. To start with these easily outperformed thier little brother the ATH-M50x which I have enjoyed, and that's why I went up a class with these MSR7BKs. I wasn't sure what to expect and wondered if they were actually worth the price. As soon as I took the packaging out of the Amazon box I could see I might have something here. I carefully worked my way through the quality packing and lifted the last layer of soft material and there nestled in a formed fitted holder was a beautiful set of headphones. Black and chrome with a blue inlay around the cup holders, I could smell the leather of the ear pads. I grabbed my amp/dac, hooked in my iPod and fired her up, as I listened I realized I was grinning at a good clean crisp wide frequency sound. These headphones capture a full range of sound very distinctly, from strong although not overpowering bass to the clear sound of light symbols, in this price range I've never heard a better sound coming from a set of headphones.I put them up against my v-moda crossfades and I only had to swap out the phones once to realize the MSR7 outperformed the v-moda. In my opinion they sound like a hopped up finely tuned set of the M50x on steroids. The ear padding is very comfortable and the tension on the cups is firm yet not too tight, there is a good range of adjustment in the headband and my rather large ears fit inside the ear pads. Nobody paid me or gave me a discount, the ATH-MSR7 are an outstanding set of cans.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 17, 2016

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great Headphones
author: Byron Goodman
content: I bought this pair and ended up not needing them but decided to keep them anyway. I am really glad I did. I have a pair of M50x's as well as with several other pairs of headphones, but these are by far my favorite set now.I can listen to music for hours without my ears having any discomfort from distorted highs or unbearable lows. I hate when people use the word sound stage, as it is something that can't be measured, though I will say that reproduction of different environments is excellent.Your audio source is going to have the greatest impact on your audio quality. If you're plugging these into a phone or PC, you're probably going to be able to hear all the feedback and distortion that already exists even better.So use a good DAC or other source with decent filters and a lossless (or as lossless as possible) audio source and you will be extremely happy with these headphones.These headphones are better than the M50x's. The clarity IMO is about an entire step above them. You will lose a little bass, but the bass in the M50x's creates annoying distortion for most music. I'm able to drive these headphones at higher volumes without any loss in clarity.I use them with the Mayflower ARC DAC. I can highly recommend it. Though I can also recommend the SMSL SD793-II if you're looking for something less expensive.As with all headphones, you will have to buy them and test them for yourself. Sound pressure level is relative to altitude, your ear canal size, and a number of other factors. We're not all hearing the same thing. Just make sure before you rate these headphones you used a good source, not your phone and not your aux port on your PC. If you have a bad source, these will make that source sound even worse.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 7, 2018

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Dethrones V-Moda M100 as the sub $500 Champion!
author: TwoTamales
content: So I own a lot of different headphones from open to closed and these are probably the best thing in between. The highs and mids are absolutely amazing and the bass is so accurate that you will never want to listen to a "over bassed" pair of phones again. I also have a pair of V-Moda M100s which I would probably list as the Champion of quality for under $500, that is until I listened on the ATH-MSR7BK.There's a new reigning champion of sound in the sub $500 market and trust me, you don't want to miss these. However, I will say the overall clarity of these are so great that you want to make sure the music you are listening to is pristine and high quality (at least 16 bit) because their accuracy has a way of really making bad recordings sound bad- not the headphone's fault.Comfort is kind of a question mark honestly, but only if you wear them for more than an hour at a time. They aren't too heavy but the fit is tight which is also a good thing because it locks more sound in and it's not escaping. I will never understand people getting a set of headphones a negative review based solely on their comfort. If you want comfort, go buy some plush cotton ear muffs. I bought these for their sound quality not their comfort which honestly isn't even the worst among headphones in this class. Also, give these some time to burn in properly, at first the highs will seem overbearing or the bass will sound more recessed but it all balances out after a good burn in ** for amateurs, this does not mean setting them on fire or sticking them under your hair drier ** Have a great time with these!PS, Lady Gaga sounds amazing on these. LOL!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 16, 2016

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars The ATH-MSR7 headphones look and sound great. I don't claim to be an audiophile and ...
author: Michael F.
content: The ATH-MSR7 headphones look and sound great. I don't claim to be an audiophile and other reviews have done a good job describing the sound, so I will just say that I really like these headphones. I didn't like the stock cables though, so I bought the red 4 ft. Anker 3.5mm Nylon Braided Auxiliary Audio Cable ( Anker 3.5mm Nylon Braided Auxiliary Audio Cable (4ft / 1.2m) Tangle-Free AUX Cable for Beats Headphones, iPods, iPhones, iPads, Home / Car Stereos and More (Red) ). The red nylon cable covering looks good with the gun metal gray / brown pair i bought, which have red accents on the cups.All the pivot points felt solid out of the box, and initially there was no creaking from plastic rubbing on plastic. However, after about two weeks the pivots loosened up a bit and the headphones made a fairy loud creaking noise if I move my head in certain ways. I did a quick google search and found that this problem exists for a variety of headphone models from different manufacturers (AKG, Audio-Technica, Sennheiser, etc.). Many forum posts suggested adding a small amount of lubricant to the pivots.I put a drop of Finish Line Dry Teflon Bike Lubricant on all the pivots (this stuff comes out of the bottle as a thick liquid and then dries to a waxy consistency, so it won't run or leak). For the ones that connect the cups to the yokes, I put the lubricant inside the inside the cups. This required removing a few screws and pulling the cups apart just enough to expose the pivots. This requires a precision phillips screwdriver but was pretty simple (you can find step-by-step instructions specifically for the MSR7 on headphone forums). Lubrication completely eliminated the creaking noises.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 3, 2016

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Good Sound For The Right Applications, But...Very Disappointed
author: Jendrasiak
content: Out of the box I was very impressed by the seemingly good build quality and comfort. They look like they're built to last and that was actually my top priority in this purchase. Also this is not a priority at all but I was impressed by the packaging and the extra provided cables.But, after a couple days of light use the faux leather is already peeling and flaking off.I’ll preface the audio quality section by admitting I’m no expert. But I have heard a decent variety of good headphones and good speakers, and do some of my own recording and editing. Also got these yesterday so I haven't had a ton of listening experience with them yet, and that which I have has been all 320 kbps mp3's streamed via Spotify.So I like them, but to be honest I am not blown away. I was using my Klipsch bookshelf speakers as a standard and with those it doesn’t really matter what I listen to, it all sounds good. With these headphones it really depends on what I’m listening to. I’ve found that the dynamics and clarity is very good in the mid range. The highs are good enough. But I also think the mid-bass and below leaves a bit to be desired. It’s not muddy or anything, but so quiet. They are not "punchy" like, I dunno, Bose headphones and I don’t want that but I definitely expected the lows to be more pronounced.I’ve seen others say the sound stage is great. I would say it's about average for over ear headphones of this price. Nothing particularly impressive.I can tell right off the bat these headphones will make great monitoring headphones for vocals. Vocals and acoustic music and classical is where they really shine for me. And of course they look beautiful.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 5, 2019

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Once you go lossless, you never go back.
author: Wendy
content: I get what everyone on here means when they say these headphones are bright. Basically they are so perfectly accurate that many songs actually don't sound as good. To be honest I'm planning on possibly upgrading my micro sd to 128gb and re-downloading in a lossless format, such as .flac. I listened to Odesza over a lossless audio file and it was phenomenal. Its like living your whole life without glasses and one day buying some.It's such a catch-22 because well mastered songs sound so vibrant and perfect, and poor aufio quality is amplified.Definately doesn't have the thumping bass, but I personally don't like heavy bass. Still even to me it seems on the light side, but maybe that's because I forget these are headphones, and not a $1000 home audio setup.I almost rated these 1 star because of a simple user error! When I got these I didn't push in the jack hard enough to get it to snap in, and as a result it felt like a loose connection and the audio was spotty. I returned these and bought another pair, same thing. I realized it was unlikely for two to come broken with such good reviews, pressed a little harder and the very firm connection snapped into place.As for build quality, these are excellent! Everythimg feels well made and sturdy, firm audio connection, all around solid construction. And hey I think they're cute too!I just bought these today, but if anything changes/goes wrong prematurely I'll update this post.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 2, 2017

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Almost perfect - great headphones but have legacy port for charging
author: Nutte
content: Love these headphones. Hope they release a new version with a USB Type C port though.Some pros and cons below...+) Wired. Seems like we get less and less options for wired headphones. Can't understand why companies release all these wireless options, but not all models comes.+) Good sound quality. I love bass and really dislike treble. I've seen others complain about some lack of bass, but I've no issues. This of course can depend on the amplifier/listening device.+) Very nice noise cancelling.-) Swivel. I like fixed headphones that doesn't fold or swivel in any way, although I don't deduct any points for this as I can understand that people who pack & unpack the phones a lot might see it as a benefit. To me though, it's just annoying. These headphones are pretty ok though, i.e. there are others that are a lot worse and just fold and swivel when you don't want them to, i.e. when putting them on.-) Micro USB charging port. This is the main reason I don't give five stars. The world has moved on to USB Type C, so it's very annoying to have to keep an extra micro USB cable/charger around just for the headphones.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 9, 2019

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Don't compare these to the ATH 50xs
author: Amazon Customer
content: When I first got these I immediately tried them out on my Lg v20 and I was initially overwhelmed by the sound. It felt like I was being bombarded with forward and hard sounding details. As someone who came from much warmer and V-sounding headphones it was extremely unpleasing to my ears and not musical whatsoever. Then, I realized that these headphones have extremely sensitive pairing to its source. My v20's DAC made the headphones harsh and coldly detailed. However, paired with an external DAP and my laptop tweaked by B&O (known for warmer+smoother sound), the sound came out finely detailed and smooth. I highly recommend finding a warmer source if you find these to be boring and overly analytical sounding. The MSR7s are said to be near reference quality leaning on bright, and I can confirm this. If you are a basshead, look elsewhere. It's not that the bass is nonexistent on these headphones but it is so clean and appropriate that you might feel like something is lacking. I mostly listen to a lot of EDM and pop music and although they sound perfectly fine, I wouldn't necessarily recommend these pair of headphones for those genres. The MSR7s are mostly a flat sound so they generally sound great with all kinds of genres but maybe Metal and Rock in particular? Anyhow, these headphones are a great deal for this price overall and a joy to listen to in the right setting. The clarity is amazing and due to their accuracy these sound like a mature pair of headphones at this low price.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Sounds Great. Propietary Cable?
author: NBAFAN
content: I must admit I hadn't use mine all that much yet. I was able to on my laptop. They sound great. Even compared to my Beyer-Dynamics DT 770 Pros. I'm unable to use them on my desktop. I have a Sound Blaster X-Fi USB sound card which requires a headset with a 1/4" plug. Instead of ordering an adapter I went and ordered some really nice Ugreen braided cords. They came in and then I realized they don't quite fit the 3.5mm plug in the headphones. Seriously? They plug in but don't quite reach the contacts enough to work properly. Seriously? Upon closer inspection I can see a difference between the cable provided and the standard plug. Had I known this I would've moved on and bought a different pair. UPDATE - Through trial and error I found a replacement cable hat fits my new headphones. Anyone looking for a cable that surpasses the design (and crazy price) of the original cables need to look no further than an iVanky Nylon Braided Aux Cord. This cable is what prevented my desire to return the headphones. Now that I'm using them on my PC I'm doubling down on what I said about these sounding great BTW.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars If you hear about people complaining about bass - it's cuz they're bass heads and enjoy bass heavy headphones
author: Daniel Guglielmo
content: OK so I've owned the 50x's for 2 years now and these went on sale for $150... what the 50x's are normally. My girlfriend has been all over my 50x's lately, so I got her these and ofc had to listen to them asap. Jesus they blow the 50x's out of the water in my opinion. I had to buy a second pair for me at this price before I missed out!The soundstage at this price is unbelievable. I still my use my 50x's in a few rare applications based on the genre since these are soooo neutral compared to the 50x. However, that said the separation of instruments and clarity - Just EVERYTHING is incredible in comparison. If you hear about people complaining about bass - it's cuz they're bass heads and enjoy bass heavy headphones. If you're looking for a neutral sound and truly going into the low end hifi headphone range. You can't beat the sale on these.All that said, I wouldn't buy these at msrp I don't think($250). I've found these most enjoyable so far testing rock studio albums so far. Classical was slightly underwhelming. I can't really go further into details yet though because I've owned these for less than 24hrs. It's 1:30 AM and I don't want to sleep because of these though.Lighter and better build quality than 50x too!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars For someone seeking portable reference quality sound, but not for the bassheads.
author: Niel Peasants
content: I never thought I could find this quality of audio in a portable set of headphones. While they do not fold the cups rotate so they take less space. They're a little tight but I have a big head and anyone else Ive known can wear these for hours and forget they're on...that being said they're comfortable , classy looking, and very well built.Low ranges are very clear, with just a touch of emphasis on bass and sub bass so the headphones. DO NOT GET THESE IF YOU NEED LOTS OF BASS.Mid ranges are exceptionally detailed, lively, and present..since buying these ive gone through various test tracks/albums and found things I have never heard in songs I know like the back of my hand.Upper mids and highs sparkle in these cans. I swear I listened to Jeff Buckley legacy edition and I could hear the tiniest vibrato in his voice and guitar playing that I cant as easily hear on my actual reference headphones.The only bad thing about these headphones is they are so clear you will find out some of your music doesnt have as good of production as you previously thought but the ones that do...MY GOD you can hear everythingTLDR: if you are an audiophile looking for stylish, reference quality sound, and not willing to pay 500+ get these. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Buy them... With a Caveat
author: TheDeepShell
content: I've got to be honest here, I have a bit of a love hate with these.I love the sound. It's excellent. It's neutral. It looks good on you. It's relatively isolating.I dislike how hard these grip your head. Period. I'm sure with time and a bit of wiggling around, it will loosen up. Right now, it just feels like it squeezes my head too much.That being said, they are still comfortable enough to wear for extended periods of time. It's really an odd thing. The pads are nice, even if it's a bit light in the headband. The high tensile strength is really the only comfort detractor.The Sound is fantastic. The bass is present, and is neither boomy or too light. You could increase the bass presence with the EQ, if you so desire, but it's not necessary for me.So yes. Buy these if you either like high tensile strength headphones, or if you can see yourself getting used to it/loosening them up.***UPDATE***I have now had these headphones for a few months, and I can happily say that they have loosened up significantly. These have morphed from headphones that were uncomfortable to wear for any substantial length of time, to headphones that are extremely comfortable. I can and have worn these for nearly 8 hours straight. If you're intentional about stretching these out, I'd say you can break them in after a couple of weeks. It's definitely worth the wait.Buy these!

content: I've kind of come to the conclusion that one just "gets used" to the sound signature of their headphones after a month or so of constant use, and I've gotten used to how crisp these headphones sound. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Rare Combination of Accuracy, Clarity, and Deep Bass
author: JT
content: As a replacement for my Sennheiser Evolutions that I purchased ~15 years ago I purchased a pair of Sennheiser HD380s. These headphones sounded wonderful but seriously lacked bass and clamped very tightly to the head, as they were studio headphones and the tight fit was to prevent bleed back to the mic. I gave those to my son and then ordered a pair of V-Moda Crossfade M-100s, These had a nice deep bass to them and were much more comfortable then the HD380s; however, they were not nearly as clean. I longed for the clarity and accuracy of the HD380s and the bass of the M-100s. Research led me to these and I am really glad it did. They have almost the clarity and precision of the HD380s and good deep bass. They are also very comfortable for those hours long listening sessions. If you are doing studio mixes then the HD380 are a better choice in this price range as they are more accurate and the clarity is a little better. However, if you are a picky audiophile who cannot afford to spend a grand or more on headphones. I would give the babies a try. You'll need a headphone amp. I am pushing mine with a Dragon Fly Red and they sound wonderful.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Superb in sound, subtle flaws in build.
author: Music Man
content: Crystal Clear sound. These are the best sounding closed backs I've used. They are well worth it for the price, but they do have their flaws.Pros:-Very Accurate sound-Neutral sound signature-good frequency respons-comfortable padsCons:-Unless perfectly positioned on your head, these make slight creaks due to flexing parts. The sound is noticeable if you listen on a quiet volume, but otherwise is no cause for concern.-Top band could use more padding. Again, unless perfectly positioned on your head, the headband will cause a hotspot.-The cable. while a nice material in and of its self, the portable 1.2 meter cables terminate in a clumsy 90 degree bend with a chunky plug. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Nice detailed sound. Great set of cans.
author: Maximus
content: I am not an audiophile, but I wanted quality headphones to listen to Classical, Jazz, Acoustics. and different styles of Rock. As a musician I am very delighted with these cans. The detailed sound is incredible and the build quality is amazing. They look great. My only complain is its shallow ear pads. They could had used memory foam, but I will later buy a pair of HM5 pads and see how they feel/sound. You can always adjust and stretch the headband if its clamping force is too hard on your head. I put it 2 days on a basketball and its perfect fit now. The trebles could be too fine for some. I let it burn with music at a bit higher volume for about 50 hrs and the trebles soften a lot. Dont expect bass, the bass is not absent, but its not the boom a basehead wants. I think its base is solid, but not the low end much people expect. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 14, 2016

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Bass roll-off is an issue
author: John T
content: This is really the only headphone purchase I regret. While the detail and soundstage are decent, the bass rolls off way to early. There is virtually no bass. I am not a bass-head (and no, I would never purchase Beats headphones), but I do like to hear some bass without straining to hear it. While the frequency response numbers indicate there is a good range of bass and sub-bass, it is at such a low decibel level, it makes this a mid-range to high frequency headphone. My ATH-M40x headphones, although not as detailed, are more pleasurable to listen to. I don't have any other closed-back headphones to compare these to, but I've got to think there are others in this price range that have a better frequency response. It would be helpful if Amazon would publish response curves like Massdrop does for many of their headphones. Unfortunately, it does not look like Audio Technica wants their sellers to reveal that information. Instead, they only publish that the response is 5-40,000 hz, which looks good until you listen to them and realize you need to EQ them to hear any bass. I am sure there are some people who love these due to the detail in the mids, but any music with bass is muted in the low end.

A really nice, well balanced and a natural sound performance. Just enough of bass, high frequencies are in check, crystal clear, natural and very authentic, rich sound. Dance, piano, violin, guitar, vocals-this headphones handle it all. The construction is very solid with high quality materials, and it feels like a very professional product. Its very steady and sits very comfortably and secure on your head without causing any discomfort even with a very prolonged listening.I am highly satisfied with the headphones which i ended up buying on Amazon since it was cheaper. Nothing can really beat such quality within this price range. I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates a great sound quality, stylish look, durable solid construction and a very decent price.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 29, 2015

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Quality build but small earcups sacrifice comfort and definitely leaks sound
author: A Customer
content: For this review I will try to stay away from the subjective (sound quality) and focus more on comfort and fit. I have a pair of 558s that I like but don't love and need something that is closed for use at the office. I was hoping these would be it. Sadly, they are not. Having tried the pro700mk2s and liking them, but returned them due to painful clamping I decided to give these a try on sale for 180. At 100 dollars more than my 558s I wasn't too impressed by the sound quality but I was mainly more disappointed that the cups aren't big enough to be comfortable for long periods (my 558s are way larger and more comfortable). My ears rub against the plastic on the inside and since there's not much room things get warm quickly. Also these leak quite a bit of noise, so if your co-workers are close by, I'd say these are a no go. The build quality did seem to be great though and you get a nice selection of cables. If you have smaller ears and like the Audio Technica sound these will probably work quite well for you. For me I will be sending these back and hopefully the 598c units will go on sale again.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 30, 2016

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Just save up and get these magnificient pair of cans.
author: Luis
content: I just bought these headphones like a month ago, I was really trying to get something outstanding in the audiophile world. I did not want to spend $300 for some Bose or Beats cans, because they are too well known, I wanted something almost unique, good looking, and good sounding. So, I was watching review after review of these ones and I fell in love. So when the paycheck came in, they were at $185 no tax, perfect timing.When I got them they were very comfy, if you are sitting on your computer you have to let time soften them out because they hurt at the beginning if you spend more than one hour with them, right at the top of your head.I really dont know about how mids and highs must sound, but the lows are really low... I missed them, but it is not such a big deal. You receive a quality product, soundstage, good lookingness, hi-res audio, 3 detachable cables and a pouch for such a low price. I love them.I used them for everything: Gaming, music, movies, have not take any phone calls on them but that does not matter.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 28, 2016

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars These headphones have great detail & clean sound with crisp mids & highs ...
author: Marvin
content: I compared these headphones to the AT MX50x, AT MX70, AT MSR7, and Yamaha MT220. These headphones have great detail & clean sound with crisp mids & highs with good dynamics. They are slightly warmer, louder, and live than the M70x but not as bright or detailed. Mids are the focus, sometimes are colored to the point you notice it. The bass is slighly more pronounced than the M70x, however it shows up more at higher volumes. Overall very good sounding headphones, particularly if you like acoustic instruments and vocals. If looking between the M70 and this, it's a toss up. These have slightly more bass (which to me is still slightly less present than for my taste, but you will deal with the colored voicing. The M70's have better imaging and overall crispness, but less bass presence.Checkout the picture for a premium headphone detailed comparison.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 24, 2016

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Quality Product
author: Stan
content: These headphones work exactly as described. I’m not an audiophile...I purchased them for tv watching. I will occasionally use them for listening to music but the primary purpose was for watching tv and they work well. These headphones replaced my Bose QC2’s that finally died after about 9 - 10 years of use. I needed a wired set to connect to my amplifier and they are hard to come by at a reasonable price. Decided to give these a try and couldn’t be happier (saved a little money to boot). I initially had some trouble getting them to work with my amplifier but after some time with customer support (who were very helpful by the way) I figured out what the problem was...operator error on my part. If you’re in the market for a set of wired headphones buy these. You won’t be sorry.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 13, 2019

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars making a lot less comfortable older model
author: Richard
content: I bought these headphones to replace my older pair because they're looking ragged and scratched up, but when I got my new pair the pads on the ear cups were a lot smaller and much denser foam than my old pair, changing the way they sound and turning from over ears to a pseudo on ear, making a lot less comfortable than older model. Over al they look the same but now the bass is louder and the treble has been quelled down to the point that the headphones sound more like a standard V-shape with good separation and detail, from being the forward sounding headphones of the older model. The pad on left is older model and the one on the right is the newer model.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 6, 2018

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Exactly what I was looking for
author: Amazon Customer
content: I looked at several comparable headphones in this price range and settled in on these. I'm a classical musician and I wanted a pair of cans that reproduce music the way it was assembled in the studio. This means an even distribution of tone from bass to high, with good representation in the mid range. I want to be able to isolate each instrument and these definitely fill the bill. Other reviews have complained about soft bass, and perhaps if your genre is hip-hop, heavy metal, or other bass heavy music, then these are probably not for you. However, I find these to be pretty even across the spectrum. S's are more slightly more evident in rock music, but I can make out each instrument, which is what I wanted. Where these really shine is in the classical genre. Put on Barber's Adagio for Strings, wait for the fermata, and you will not be disappointed.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2017

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic headphones! I use them daily
author: Garrus V.
content: Fantastic headphones! I use them daily, and they sound awesome with the kind of music I listen to (Rock, folk, jazz). Fairly comfortable right off the bat, but I got a headband cushion due to the fact that the headband is a bit wide so the point of contact is small and can get sore after long periods of use. The pads are nice but I would recommend larger ones if you plan on using them for hours on end or have large ears. Highs are fantastic, and genres that are mid and high heavy are amazing in these. Mids are also great, although not as good as the highs due to the slight V shaped sound. Low end is very very clean and modest, so most bassy songs will sound great on these, although if you're a fan of the Beats sound or are a bass head, I wouldn't recommend these without some sort of bass boost. Overall fantastic and well worth the price.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 12, 2016

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars A Bit Bright
author: Trish
content: This was my first experience with higher quality headphones. I had not experienced sound outside of my 5 year old Sol Republics, so I figured I would test these out just to start somewhere.I did my research up front, so I went in knowing that these offer brighter sounds and that the bass will be less noticeable. That is definitely the case. I felt that the depth of the my music taste (chill EDM, think ODESZA) was a bit too lost in the brightness of these.In addition to the lost depth, another reviewer mentioned that his "ears seem to work hard with these on..." - I would absolutely agree. I listen to music fairly loud around 5 hours out of a typical work day, and I could only do maybe an hour straight of listening before feeling the need to give my ears a break.All in all, I LOVE the look and feel of these and wish they would have worked, but guess I have learned I need a bit warmer tone. If you're in the market for brighter cans, these would be a great option.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 6, 2018

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Happy
author: BuckWheat
content: I bought these to use as studio monitors for my home recording studio. If you are looking for the artificial boost in bass that seems to be desirable by many listeners then look elsewhere. I was looking for a pair with a flat neutral response and that is what I got. Read many reviews for these as well as others and for the price range these seemed to fit the bill and they have. Very happy with my selection and would give it 4 1/2 stars if possible. For non-studio use I run these through a OPPO HA-2SE amp hooked up to a iPod touch or a Sony ZX100 DAP and the headphones sound great for that use as well.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 18, 2017

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Astounding audio and build quality. I'm never buying a gaming headset again.
author: Alex
content: I've had these for a few months and this is what I've got to add to the conversation:-The overall build quality and comfort is ASTOUNDING, as someone who is used to "gaming headsets", these blew me away.-The bass is pretty lowkey. However, a little EQ can go a long way to make these do whatever you need them to do.-The audio quality is about as crisp as a fallen leaf on some fresh snow. It's glorious.-The headband can be a bit tight, and it doesn't slack much after a long time of wear, so if you've got a big head be careful. You know who you are.-They function great with an external microphone, even managed to get it working with my console! (utilizing an external microphone and a 3.5mm extension cable)I ABSOLUTELY recommend these to ANYONE looking for a new headset, especially if you're tired of replacing gaming headsets every few years.

With these I heard parts in recordings that I didn't realize were there. Part of me wishes I could justify owning these and the vmodas but I just don't need two headphnes.Comfort was OK. It wasn't comfortable but it wasn't uncomfortable either. There wasn't a whole lot of pressure on my head with these but it was noticeable that they were on my head.I only had them for a few days so I can't speak for durability, I don't know that I would carry these around much or take them on trips without a hard shell case, which they don't come with.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Happy Customer

content: I bought this just in time for an International trip that lasted about 15.5 hours in a stretch. It does not cancel out the voices when at home which is a good thing. And the music quality is excellent.Overall, I am a happy customer. There are a few things that could be better with this product. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 27, 2016

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Too bright, not for all music styles
author: uncompensated reviewer
content: Remember when we listened to amplifiers/ receivers that had bass and treble knobs. These headphones sound like the treble has been turned up all the way and the bass has been turned down nearly all the way. I listened to these on an s5, kindle fire hd, and apple i pad mini.The sound was not very good on any of these three devices considering the price point. If you like bright, high treble sound with very subdued bass response then these are the right headphones for you. These headphones do have good clarity but the bass response, sound is lacking. If you like to listen to music with amplified heavy bass don't buy these headphones. This model does have very good build quality and the comfort level is adequate if you're not listening for an extended period of time. Overall this set will not properly suit all music styles and is not well rounded from low to high frequencies. The MSR7 is best driven by a DAC/AMP setup, our portable devices can't properly drive these cans and unleash their full potential.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 5, 2017

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best headphones I've ever had!
author: Daniel G.
content: I'm no audiophile, just a regular guy who wanted to experience music with a pair of good quality headphones. When I first got them, the package did look all premium, after all one does pay top dollar. I was using before some good, quality Phillips headphones. I was listening to a high definition song with my Phillips, then put these headphones on and then the Philips again. Man! These made the Philips sound like cats fighting in a dumpster, when for years I was convinced my previous headphones were of the best class. One does experience a whole new level of quality, even with lossy mp3 music.I have nothing against the Philips and it was my preferred brand for years, and I think they are an excellent brand compared to others in the price range, but the $50 Phillips headphones I had were no competition for these Audio Technica.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Nice headphones, except for the cables.
author: A. Leonard
content: I mostly listen to MP3s and streaming audio from Netflix and Amazon Prime these days, which is obviously not the best source material to base audio quality on. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 8, 2017

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars COUNTERFEIT WARNING
author: Kyle
content: These headphones are great! I’m not an audiophile (yet) so I won’t get into the nitty gritty. However I did want to warn people that the first pair of headphones that I ordered from the seller OneWAY were confirmed to be counterfeit by Audio-Technica. The first picture shows the fake headphones, after taking off the ear pads, I noticed how there are only 3 mounting screws per ear cup. The second picture is what the ear cup should look like. Audio-Technica gave me a list of approved sellers which I will attach below. I ordered my headphones from Gramophone and they are 100% real.Approved list given by Audio-Technica:Any of the ones listed at $199 or higher are coming from authorized dealers such as Gramophone, Better Home NJ, Pavillion Electronics, BeachAudio

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Headphones - but not for everyone
author: James
content: Very good sound quality. Sturdy build.Noise cancelling feature is intentionally mild on these by-design so that sound quality is the same with it turned on or off. But be aware that the active noise cancelling on these does not completely cancel-out background noise.Sound quality is very good, but as other reviews mention, treble/sibilance is very high on these. So, if you are sensitive to that, these headphones can be intense / fatiguing over long listening sessions.If you are looking for something with less treble, the ATH 50s are also excellent.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 10, 2019

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Clearest Cans
author: Samuel J. Cedar
content: You can truly experience your music with these headphones. The trebles and mids are oh-so-clear, and the bass is just punchy enough to be exciting without overpowering other frequency ranges. The are rather tiring on the ears, and they do sounds very bright. However, for string instruments in particular, these are the clearest sounding headphones that I have heard. I actually like how active the sound is, it makes the music sound more true to reality. The build quality is good enough - it's a bit creaky and doesn't come with great accessories, but that isn't why I bought these headphones in the first place. If you want exceptional sound - buy them. If you want aesthetic appeal, comfort, and a headphone that will allow to listen to music more passively, then maybe go with the Sony MDR-1A.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 2, 2016

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Blown away by the sound quality
author: Dustin Brecht
content: I purchased these headphones for $150, and at that price point I am extremely happy with my purchse. I previously have used VModa Crossfade LP, Audio Technica ATH-M40x, Audio Technica ATH-M50x, Shure SE215, as well as a variety of budget headphones. The ATH-MSR7BK SonicPro headphones outperform all of these by a noticeable margin. Listening to music with them is truly an amazing experience. I hear things that I hadn't noticed before in music that I am quite familiar with. Across the spectrum, from bass to high treble, the balance is incredible. Bassheads may not be happy with this, but if you like a well balanced sound, I don't think there is a better option in this price range.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2019

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These probably aren't the right choice for bass heads (Sennheiser Momentum 2 would be better, but you lose the accuracy and deta
author: Quiet Gardener
content: These phones are reference grade headphones at a consumer friendly price. Absolutely superb detail and clarity. The bass is solid and well controlled throughout, rolling off at around 30 hz. They do require well mastered recordings though because they are more than capable of exposing every flaw, especially if the flaw is at the high end of the spectrum.Bass, while solid, is neutral. These probably aren't the right choice for bass heads (Sennheiser Momentum 2 would be better, but you lose the accuracy and detail). Other than that I haven't heard anything else in the price range these play in that sounds better, or actually anything costing twice as much.A headphone amp does improve the lower end especially when playing loud, but my iPhone drives them just fine at moderate levels and I'm pretty picky.I'd recommend these to anyone
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2016

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sounds quite awesome with some tweaking and yes the cable matters
author: Ryon
content: Sounds quite awesome with some tweaking and yes the cable matters. Mobile devices use the L cable and for computers use the long straight cable, also do some tweaking in the EQ on the computer by right clicking on the speaker and going to playback devices and then the advanced settings in that and pick what sounds best for you. Also if you have a headphone port on the front of your computer it won't give good power so use the motherboard Jack on the back. They do bring out instruments you've never even heard. I cannot stress this enough if you just listen to badly recorded mp3 tracks then I'd give this set a pass...it exposes bad recording

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Port mismatch.
author: Mike Mallick
content: First of all, allow me to thank the awesome Amazon return program. Moving on, this is a very well constructed product (translated: metal parts not plastic where it counts). The noise cancellation is underwhelming. Next issue? The charging wire will fit only a port configuration phased out on Apples latest iPhone.
